Story highlights Trump slammed Sessions as well as the investigation into potential coordination between his associates and Russia

He said it would be wrong for Mueller to look at his family's finances

Washington (CNN) President Donald Trump said in an interview published Wednesday that he would not have chosen Jeff Sessions to be his attorney general had he known Sessions would recuse himself over matters related to the 2016 presidential campaign.

Trump's remarks, in a 50-minute interview with The New York Times , represent an extraordinary rebuke from the President toward the nation's top law enforcement official who happens to be one of his earliest political allies.

JUST WATCHED Sessions' testimony in 2 minutes Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Sessions' testimony in 2 minutes 02:10

But several months into the job, Trump's warm feelings for Sessions have clearly cooled.
Before Trump had a lock on the Republican nomination last year, Sessions became the first sitting senator to back the real estate mogul's presidential bid.
"Jeff Sessions takes the job, gets into the job, recuses himself, which frankly I think is very unfair to the President," Trump said, referring to himself.
In the interview, Trump scolded Sessions for telling the Senate judiciary committee that he had not met with any Russians during the campaign.
If he would have recused himself before the job, I would have said, 'Thanks, Jeff, but I'm not going to take you.'
It was later revealed he had met with Sergey Kislyak, the Russian ambassador to the US, at least two times.
It's extremely unfair -- and that's a mild word -- to the President."
"How do you take a job and then recuse yourself?
